title: Domain 4.3: Explain various activities associated with vulnerability management.
content:
🕵️ Identification Methods

🔍 Vulnerability Scan

  • Automated tool scans systems for known vulnerabilities—non-intrusive, but may miss logic flaws.

🔐 Application Security

🧱 Static Analysis

  • Examines source code without executing it—finds issues like hardcoded secrets or insecure libraries.

🏃 Dynamic Analysis

  • Analyzes app behavior at runtime—can detect flaws like memory leaks, injection, etc.

📦 Package Monitoring

  • Watches for vulnerabilities in third-party libraries or dependencies used in the application.

🌐 Threat Feed

🌎 Open-Source Intelligence (OSINT)

  • Publicly available data (e.g., blogs, forums, security bulletins) used to identify emerging threats.

🏢 Proprietary/Third-Party

  • Paid or subscription-based feeds offering curated and vetted threat intelligence.

🤝 Information-Sharing Organization

  • Groups like ISACs or government agencies that share threat data across sectors.

🌑 Dark Web

  • Monitoring hacker forums or marketplaces for signs of exposed data, credentials, or exploits.

💣 Penetration Testing

  • Simulated real-world attack to uncover vulnerabilities—often manual, skilled, and rules-of-engagement driven.

🧑‍💻 Responsible Disclosure Program

  • Incentivizes ethical hackers to report vulnerabilities in exchange for rewards—helps identify real-world flaws.

📋 System / Process Audit

  • Formal review of configurations, policies, and procedures to uncover security weaknesses or non-compliance.

🧠 Analysis

✅ Confirmation

  • Identifies that the vulnerability truly exists.

🚫 False Positive

  • Alert says there's a vulnerability—but there isn't. Wastes time and resources.

❌ False Negative

  • A real vulnerability goes undetected—can lead to a silent compromise.

🧮 Prioritize

  • Determine which vulnerabilities to fix first based on risk, impact, and likelihood.

📊 CVSS (Common Vulnerability Scoring System)

  • Industry-standard scoring system (0–10) to rate the severity of a vulnerability.

🔢 CVE (Common Vulnerability Enumeration)

  • Unique identifiers for known vulnerabilities—helps standardize tracking and sharing (e.g., CVE-2023-1234).

🗂️ Vulnerability Classification

  • Organizing vulnerabilities by type (e.g., buffer overflow, privilege escalation) to aid in mitigation strategies.

🌡️ Exposure Factor

  • Estimate of how much damage a vulnerability could cause if exploited.

🌍 Environmental Variables

  • Factors like operating system, network architecture, and usage context that affect a vulnerability's risk level.

🏢 Industry/Organizational Impact

  • Some vulnerabilities matter more in specific sectors (e.g., healthcare, finance)—tailor analysis accordingly.

🎯 Risk Tolerance

  • The level of risk an organization is willing to accept—shapes mitigation priorities and resource allocation.

🛠️ Vulnerability Response & Remediation

🔧 Patching

  • Apply security updates to fix vulnerabilities—must be timely to prevent exploitation.

🛡️ Insurance

  • Cyber insurance helps mitigate financial impact if a vulnerability is exploited.

🧱 Segmentation

  • Isolate vulnerable systems to limit potential damage and lateral movement.

🪪 Compensating Controls

  • Alternative safeguards used when ideal security measures (like patching) can’t be applied immediately.

🧾 Exceptions & Exemptions

  • Official approvals to delay or avoid remediation—must be documented and risk-assessed.

🔍 Validation of Remediation

♻️ Rescanning

  • Re-run vulnerability scans to confirm the issue has been resolved.

📋 Audit

  • Independent review of remediation steps to verify compliance and effectiveness.

✅ Verification

  • Confirm the vulnerability is no longer exploitable—often through testing or validation tools.

🗒️ Reporting

  • Document the vulnerability, analysis, response, and validation—essential for compliance, lessons learned, and trend analysis.
